abstracts.cdata!:
Ratings for the Agricultural Research
            and Pilot Extension Project for Algeria were as follows:
            outcomes were highly unsatisfactory, project sustainability
            was unlikely, Bank performance was satisfactory, and
            Borrower performance was also satisfactory. Some lessons
            learned included: major institutional issues should be
            solved as a condition for negotiations; this would have
            prevented National Institute for Agricultural Research
            (INRAA) from spending precious time away from project
            implementation. Programming and budgeting by objective is a
            complex approach that took INRAA nearly four years to put in
            place. Thus, the local context, capacity, and limitations of
            implementing agencies should be carefully assessed and
            analyzed during preparation. When research embarks on
            complex restructuring and adoption of a fundamentally
            different approach, fast disbursement should not be expected
            from project onset.  Modifying the approach to extension,
            especially at the national level, requires having a vision
            and defining a strategy at an early stage, together with
            extensive and effective participation by farmers. For lack
            of both at project onset, it took National Institute for
            Agricultural Extension (INVA) more time than anticipated to
            play the vital role of testing various approaches to
            extension on a pilot basis. Given the country and the
            diversity of farmers, it is most likely that the Training
            and Visit (T&V) approach to extension will prove
            inadequate on a national scale. When elaborating a strategy,
            decision makers must decide whether extension should remain
            the sole responsibility of the public sector or should be a
            mix of public and private interventions. They should also
            decide the level of farmers' contributions to the cost
            of extension, and the amount of funds the Government is
            ready to commit o extension on a regular and long-term basis.
